I'm wracking my brain trying to figure this one out. I created a simple metro line between two stops to help elleviate the traffic on the bridge. The top one and the right-side one were the first I set up, and they automatically created a back-and-forth line between themselves. [http://i.imgur.com/qqegreO.png](http://i.imgur.com/qqegreO.png)

This really didn't seem to work because I was getting an average of 14 or so travellers on the metro per week. So I added the third line (which does seem to have helped quite a bit) but... the first back-and-forth line is still there. I can't figure out how to delete it. I looked it up online and people say "Go into the transit overlay in the upper left" But there is no "transit overlay" only a transportation one, and I can't see anything that can help me delete old routes in there.

So, yeah. How do I delete old metro routes that are messing up my otherwise perfect loop?

EDIT:

I FOUND IT. It's weird, but if you have the transportation tab open, you can't view the actual transport overlay. You have to exit the one where you build the stuff in order to go into the overlay where you can delete or rename the lines. [http://i.imgur.com/KNelVwG.png](http://i.imgur.com/KNelVwG.png)

> 
> My intersection previously shown works OK. It's basically a triple roundabout, just looking rather polygonal. On the other hand some of my other roundabouts are really snarling up because the traffic is Doing It Wrong, people on the roundabout stop to let newcomers on and it gridlocks. I need to experiment more, and probably suck it up that buildings nearby are gonna get demolished all the time.

Please note that sharp turns seriously hamper traffic flow, as cars actually slow down more for sharper corners. Making roads flow visually also makes traffic flow better. Shallow turns and merges and lazy turns are best. 

Also be advised there is a mod [that lets you add or remove traffic lights](http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=411833858). It is a great way of tuning your traffic flow.

*"They've said I shouldn't be a traffic engineer, They were right "*

I presume this is not an American game because I have yet to see a three or five lane road. Dedicated turning lanes. How hard is it, really? And why, oh please tell me why, does my budget allotment for train services have anything to do with how many *freight trains* run? Money-sink commuter rail I can understand, but why am I paying the shipping fees for my industry?!

It's by a Finnish company actually. But to be honest it's missing a lot of stuff you'll see in all countries. The difficulty in making proper roundabouts, and absolute lack of mini-roundabouts, is just as irksome to me as a Brit.

Still, on balance I can't say it's anything less than a really good game, and a strong candidate for best city builder now. There's already a ton of flexibility - it's having that that ends up highlighting the shortcomings I feel. And there's already a boatload of mods too.

Is it just me, or does reducing taxes not seem to change happiness at all?

I cut it all the way down to 6% for everyone and the happiness graph hasn't changed for a good 6 years now. The happiness is plateau-ed pretty much where it's been since my city got big. Does it take even longer before happiness kicks in? Or should I just keep taxes high and slap parks everywhere?

Grand Central is already available in the Deluxe Edition, and probably also on Steam. Do not let that stop you from modding though, the more the merrier. 

I must say, KSP without mods can be painful sometimes, but this feels and functions like a well rounded game even without tweaking it too much.

Money doesn't buy you happiness ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif)
More seriously, in my experience *raising* them too much makes leave. I nearly bankrupted my city doing that by falling into a vicious circle of raise tax rate > people leave > tax revenue declines > raise tax rate. Conversely lowering them might stimulate growth.

The real-world counterpart: [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Back-to-back_houses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Back-to-back_houses) . Taking the approach in Cities is neat because it gives you a high population density without the effects on demographics that "high density" has.

I setup a little ore mining town (from what I can tell it's right on top of a good deposit), set the neighborhood to be set as a mining industry, but in that overlay it shows no ore being used. Strange. Keep in mind that if no ore is mined then the business that need it will import it, so you might still see ore trucks.
